title: What are the biggest problems facing Brazil? - Quora

response.answer_text: After living in Brazil for 17 years, as a Canadian, American and European by birth, I see a few problems in Brazil. Before I start I will say that every single country has problems, that no country is perfect, that every single country has problems in certain areas. Okay, with that said, here are my opinions, with the biggest problem first and reducing in importance as I go: There is a huge disparity between the social classes in Brazil. Minimum wage is very low, about $250 dollars a month. The average family makes around $650 dollars a month while about 10% of the population makes $3,000 to $10,000 a month or even more - these people lead exceptionally comfortable lives while a large proportion of the population suffer financially.The public education system isn’t adequate enough for the poorer population, the middle class has to pay for private school for their children to get a decent education and therefore get a decent job. The government is investing billions in education, but there’s still a ways to go yet.In certain neighborhoods crime is rampant, especially in Rio de Janeiro. The army often occupies the rampant neighborhoods and the poor inhabitants who have nothing to do with crime who live there often suffer the consequences brutally. Personally, I’ve not been a victim of crime here, as most Brazilians who live far from these neighborhoods haven’t been victims. Although, I must say, despite what the media and many native Brazilians might say who haven’t traveled abroad, I feel much safer where I live and work now than when I grew up in Buffalo and Pittsburgh and lived Los Angeles and San Diego. I am not afraid to walk around after dark here. Although you’re reading a post from someone who lived through the Summer of Sam in New York City, so it’s all relative to the individual.Enforcement of the law is non-existent in parts of the country, and often lax in a good portion of the country. People basically do what they want and the police are benevolent. For the 99% of society that is honorable it works, it’s the 1% who aren’t that take advantage of the system who cause the problems. Thinking along these lines society is much freezer in Brazil than in the USA or other developed countries. Here I do what I want, how I want, when I want and nothing will happen to me. There is more freedom in anarchy than in a tightly controlled society.The country lacks infrastructure in certain areas. The farther inland from the coast you go the less infrastructure there is. There are towns without doctors or schools or water or electricity. Think of it like Northern Canada, there are vast areas where you are all alone in the wilderness without anything but yourself. Now apply this concept to enforcement, you can do pretty much do what you want in the wilderness and you won’t get caught for it. Obviously, in the city it’s not so easy.Brazil is so very far removed from the rest of the world geographically that what happens in the Northern hemisphere has little impact here and also visa-versa. That means that things take a little longer to change here, although with the internet as it is today, perceptions are changing rapidly and Brazilians are demanding change from their government. It’s actually working too, to a certain extent.Brazil has a party culture, go to the beach and drink, throw a barbecue and make noise, dance at Carnaval until you drop in sweat, they are social people who love to touch in conversation, for an American this can be disconcerting, although it’s not really a problem, it’s actually a good thing because people relate to each other on an deeper emotional level here in Brazil in comparison to other countries - families are much closer to each other and support each other much more than families in Europe or America do.Despite the negative, for me Brazil has been amazing, the culture, the language, the way of living, everything about this place carries has carried a unique and certain magic to it for me. I can’t explain it, you’ll have to visit to catch a glimpse and you’ll have to live here for a long time to truly understand. Brazilians are happy people, despite their problems. They love their country and even if they immigrate somewhere else, Brazil always lives in their heart. I find that beautiful… it’s just like the American expat who loves the states or the Canadian who loves Canada and goes to another place. Their country will always be theirs, but where they live can also become special to them. I hope that you enjoyed this post and that you are able to see that it’s not unsafe here… Visit if you can, it’s well worth the trip, I know, I’ve lived here. Cheers!
